ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic music theory: notation, harmony, melody, rhythm.
I learned some basic music theory. While the class focused on western musical thought, it also gave a lot of insight into non-western musical traditions.
This class helped develop my pitch skills and music notation abilities.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: I know a lot more about music theory than I did before. Homework was graded for completion and included feedback about the correct answer so you weren't afraid to make mistakes and could learn from them.

Weaknesses: The workload was way too much for a class that doesn't satisfy any distributional requirements. The expectations required a whole bunch outside studying, which was simply not worth it.

I enjoyed learned about the other, non-western music.

I think that the expectations for the students were sometimes too high, especially in regards to hearing musical pitches. We learned the basics of musical notes, progressions, and harmonies then were expected to know them by ear the following week. I think there could have been a lot more attention paid to practicing listening to music than there was in class.
Weakness: This is not a beginner class. Everyone in my section who didnt have music experience dropped

I wish we spent more time on our relative pitch and ear training but other than that I thought the class was good. It was slightly fast paced but the content was very good and I felt like I had learned a lot.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lectures weren't recorded, but my instructor posted the slides so that was good. Would have been nice if the lectures were recorded.

The access to the lecture slides were really helpful. The lectures themselves could be hard to follow sometimes, due to the extended amount of screen time's affect on focus along with various internet issues. It would have been nice to have notes or something similar to follow.

The homework was also really helpful in developing and practicing the concepts we discussed in class.
I do not think there was much to improve in terms of COVID.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No, I would not unless they're okay with either a) working harder than necessary or b) getting a lower grade for not meeting unreasonable expectations.

I would not unless they are actively seeking to pursue a hobby or career related to music. This class is really difficult, and I had a musical background. Without that background, I'm not sure I would have been able to get through the class. It doesn't seem like this class is geared towards people who are casually interested in music/who don't have some sort of experience interacting deeply with music. I do think that for someone who is considering a career in music, this class would be able to help them learn a lot more about their major and the requirements.
No. There are definitely other courses at Yale that are much better. The pace of the class is inconsistent and the content is disorganized.
I would recommend this course to anyone who wants to get their foot in the door for music.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: there were not many other types of learning modes.
